biocompatibility.title: Biocompatibility Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
biocompatibility.heroDescription: Success with blood-contacting devices depends on proving your materials don't trigger clotting, cause cell damage, or produce allergic reactions that compromise patient safety. We conduct ISO 10993 biocompatibility testing with protocols adapted for cardiovascular applications, measuring biological responses that determine whether FDA accepts your device materials as safe for human use.
biocompatibility.primaryContentDescription:
Device materials interact with blood, tissue, and immune systems in ways that standard engineering tests cannot predict. Biocompatibility testing measures whether your materials damage cells in laboratory culture, whether they trigger immune responses that cause inflammation or allergic reactions, and whether blood clots form when it contacts your device surface. These biological responses determine patient safety and regulatory approval for any device that touches human tissue.

We test cytotoxicity by exposing cells to your device materials and measuring cell death or metabolic damage. Hemocompatibility protocols measure platelet activation, complement system triggering, and clot formation when blood contacts device surfaces. Sensitization studies determine whether materials cause allergic reactions, while systemic toxicity testing evaluates effects on organs and body systems after device implantation.

ISO 10993 establishes the testing framework FDA requires, with specific protocols selected based on how long your device contacts tissue and where it's used in the body. Blood-contacting devices require hemocompatibility testing that surface-contact devices don't need. Permanent implants require long-term tissue response studies. We design testing matrices that address your specific device characteristics while meeting the standards FDA reviewers expect to see.

capabilities.title: Cytotoxicity Testing (ISO 10993-5)
capabilities.description: We expose cell cultures to device materials and measure cell viability, membrane integrity, and metabolic function to detect materials that cause cellular damage.

capabilities.title: Hemocompatibility Assessment
capabilities.description: Blood compatibility protocols measure platelet activation, thrombus formation, complement system triggering, and hemolysis to evaluate thrombosis risk for blood-contacting devices.

capabilities.title: Sensitization and Irritation Testing (ISO 10993-10)
capabilities.description: Studies determine whether device materials trigger allergic reactions or cause tissue irritation, using validated protocols that FDA accepts for regulatory submissions.

capabilities.title: Systemic Toxicity Evaluation (ISO 10993-11)
capabilities.description: Testing measures effects on major organ systems and overall health following device exposure, identifying potential systemic safety concerns before clinical use.

capabilities.title: Implantation Testing (ISO 10993-6)
capabilities.description: Protocols evaluate local tissue responses to implanted materials, measuring inflammation, tissue integration, and long-term compatibility for permanently implanted devices.

capabilities.title: Material Characterization and Extract Testing
capabilities.description: Chemical analysis identifies leachable compounds from device materials, while extract testing evaluates biological responses to substances that may migrate from devices into tissue.

fda-regulatory-testing.title: FDA Regulatory Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
fda-regulatory-testing.heroDescription: Successful FDA submissions depend on testing that answers the specific questions reviewers ask about your device type, using methods they recognize and trust. We design preclinical testing strategies aligned with current FDA guidance documents, consensus standards, and regulatory pathway requirements that generate data reviewers evaluate.
fda-regulatory-testing.primaryContentDescription:
FDA reviewers evaluate whether your testing demonstrates safety and effectiveness for the specific claims you're making. A 510(k) clearance requires showing your device works like an approved predicate through comparative testing. PMA approval demands comprehensive safety databases and effectiveness evidence from pivotal studies. IDE applications need preclinical data proving it's safe to begin human testing. Each pathway has distinct evidence requirements that determine which tests FDA expects to see.

We design testing strategies based on FDA guidance documents specific to your device type, whether that's heart valves following specific durability protocols, stents requiring fracture resistance testing, or novel devices needing risk-based testing approaches. Testing includes biocompatibility per ISO 10993, performance validation using ASTM or ISO consensus standards, and safety assessment addressing known device risks. All studies follow GLP protocols that create the documentation FDA trusts.

Your regulatory pathway determines testing scope and endpoints. 510(k) substantial equivalence testing compares your device directly to predicate performance. PMA studies require statistically powered safety and effectiveness endpoints. Breakthrough designation or De Novo pathways need innovative testing approaches that address novel technologies. We match testing design to regulatory strategy, generating data that addresses your submission requirements.

capabilities.title: 510(k) Substantial Equivalence Testing
capabilities.description: Comparative studies demonstrate your device performs similarly to cleared predicates, using matched test methods and head-to-head protocols that support equivalence claims FDA requires.

capabilities.title: Consensus Standards Implementation

capabilities.description: Risk-based ISO 10993 testing selection addresses your device's tissue contact category, duration, and anatomical location with the specific tests FDA expects for your device type.

capabilities.title: Performance Validation Under Worst-Case Conditions
capabilities.description: Testing evaluates device function at specification limits, anatomical extremes, and challenging deployment scenarios that demonstrate robustness for clinical use.

liquid-embolic-device-testing.title: Liquid Embolic Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
liquid-embolic-device-testing.heroDescription: Liquid embolic agents face unique validation challenges requiring polymer viscosity measurement, radiopacity verification, and polymerization timing control that standard biocompatibility testing cannot address. We test DMSO compatibility, tantalum suspension stability, controlled precipitation behavior, and tissue uptake patterns across aneurysm, AVM, and peripheral embolization applications for both 510(k) and PMA submissions.
liquid-embolic-device-testing.primaryContentDescription: Liquid embolic agents must solidify at precisely the right speed during deployment. Too fast and the polymer blocks your delivery catheter. Too slow and it flows beyond the target vessel before hardening. We test how viscosity changes during injection, measure polymerization timing under different conditions, and verify that tantalum particles stay suspended throughout the procedure so your device remains visible under fluoroscopy. We track polymer behavior using real-time imaging that captures precipitation patterns as liquid transitions to solid. DMSO compatibility testing ensures your carrier solvent doesn't damage microcatheters during extended procedures. Advanced tissue analysis measures how deeply the polymer penetrates vessel walls and surrounding tissue. Our protocols evaluate coating uniformity, radiopacity across different thicknesses, and complete occlusion effectiveness in anatomically accurate aneurysm models. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide material evaluation while device-specific protocols address DMSO toxicity, polymer degradation, and tissue response at embolization sites. Our testing supports both 510(k) pathways for devices similar to established embolics and PMA submissions for novel formulations. Whether validating polymer viscosity for aneurysm treatment or characterizing precipitation control for AVM applications, our catheterization laboratories provide the imaging and measurement capabilities liquid embolic validation requires.

capabilities.title: Polymer Viscosity and Flow Measurement
capabilities.description: We measure how easily your liquid embolic flows through microcatheters at different temperatures and injection speeds, tracking viscosity changes that affect delivery control and occlusion success.

capabilities.title: Polymerization Timing and Precipitation Control
capabilities.description: Real-time imaging captures how fast your polymer solidifies after contacting blood or tissue, measuring precipitation rates that determine whether the embolic stays where you place it.

capabilities.title: Radiopacity and Imaging Visibility
capabilities.description: Fluoroscopic testing verifies that tantalum or other radiopaque markers provide clear visualization during injection and follow-up, measuring visibility across different polymer thicknesses and vessel sizes.

capabilities.title: DMSO Compatibility and Carrier Safety
capabilities.description: Specialized protocols test whether DMSO damages microcatheter materials during extended procedures while evaluating tissue toxicity and vascular response to the carrier solvent.

capabilities.description: Histological analysis measures how deeply polymer penetrates aneurysm walls and surrounding tissue, mapping distribution patterns that predict occlusion completeness and durability.

capabilities.description: Anatomically accurate models test complete vessel sealing across aneurysm, AVM, and peripheral applications, measuring immediate occlusion success and long-term stability under pulsatile flow.

thrombectomy-testing.title: Thrombectomy Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
thrombectomy-testing.heroDescription: Successful thrombectomy requires devices that grab clots effectively, retrieve them without vessel damage, and achieve complete recanalization on the first attempt. We test stent retriever deployment mechanics, aspiration force generation, clot extraction efficiency, and first-pass success rates across stroke, MI, and peripheral thrombosis applications for both 510(k) and PMA submissions.
thrombectomy-testing.primaryContentDescription: Thrombectomy devices must grab clots effectively without tearing blood vessels during retrieval. Stent retrievers need to expand precisely to engage thrombus while maintaining vessel wall contact. Aspiration catheters must generate enough suction to pull clots out without fragmenting them. We test how devices perform across fresh platelet-rich clots and older organized thrombi because different clot types require different removal forces and techniques. Our protocols measure clot engagement success using force sensors that track how well devices capture thrombus during deployment. High-speed imaging documents retrieval mechanics while tracking whether clots break apart and send fragments downstream. We evaluate vessel preservation by measuring endothelial damage after multiple retrieval attempts. Anatomically accurate stroke models replicate cerebral vessel tortuosity while pulsatile flow systems simulate physiological conditions during emergency procedures. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide material safety evaluation while thrombectomy-specific protocols assess rapid deployment requirements and emergency use scenarios. Our testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices similar to cleared retrievers and PMA submissions for novel clot removal mechanisms. Whether validating stent retriever expansion for stroke intervention or measuring aspiration efficiency for coronary thrombectomy, our neurovascular laboratories provide the imaging capabilities and clot models mechanical thrombectomy validation requires.

capabilities.description: We measure how much force devices need to capture and remove different clot types, tracking engagement success rates and retrieval mechanics that predict clinical performance across stroke and thrombosis scenarios.

capabilities.title: First-Pass Recanalization Success
capabilities.description: Testing protocols evaluate complete clot removal on the first retrieval attempt using TICI scoring systems, measuring the critical performance metric that correlates with patient outcomes in stroke intervention.

capabilities.title: Vessel Wall Preservation and Safety
capabilities.description: Specialized protocols assess endothelial damage after retrieval attempts, measuring vessel trauma that could cause perforation or dissection during emergency thrombectomy procedures in delicate cerebral vessels.

capabilities.title: Distal Embolization Prevention
capabilities.description: High-speed imaging captures clot fragmentation during retrieval while sensitive particle detection measures embolic debris release, quantifying the safety risk of sending clot fragments to downstream vessels.

capabilities.description: For stent-based devices, we test radial force generation, vessel apposition quality, and clot integration patterns using fluoroscopy that documents deployment precision in tortuous neurovascular anatomy.

capabilities.title: Aspiration System Performance
capabilities.description: Aspiration catheter testing measures vacuum generation, flow rates through different catheter sizes, and extraction efficiency across varying clot compositions to optimize suction-based thrombectomy effectiveness.

direct-aspiration-thrombectomy-testing.title: Direct Aspiration Thrombectomy Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
direct-aspiration-thrombectomy-testing.heroDescription: Aspiration thrombectomy success depends on generating sufficient vacuum force, maintaining catheter trackability through tortuous vessels, and extracting clots without fragmentation. We test suction pressure generation, catheter navigation performance, clot extraction efficiency across fresh and organized thrombi, and complete recanalization achievement for stroke, coronary, and peripheral applications supporting both 510(k) and PMA pathways.
direct-aspiration-thrombectomy-testing.primaryContentDescription: Direct aspiration catheters must generate enough suction to pull clots from occluded vessels while staying flexible enough to navigate tortuous anatomy. Too much vacuum and the catheter collapses inward. Too little and clots won't budge. We measure how much negative pressure your catheter generates at different flow rates and track whether that suction stays consistent during extended procedures across varying catheter diameters and lengths. Our protocols test extraction success across different clot types because fresh platelet-rich thrombi extract differently than organized fibrin material. Force measurement systems track how much suction each clot composition requires while high-speed imaging documents whether clots come out intact or fragment during aspiration. We evaluate catheter deliverability through anatomically accurate stroke models that replicate cerebral vessel tortuosity. Pulsatile flow systems simulate physiological conditions that affect vacuum transmission from pump to catheter tip. ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide blood contact evaluation while aspiration-specific protocols assess vacuum effects on vessel walls and hemolysis potential. Our testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices similar to cleared aspiration catheters and PMA submissions for novel vacuum generation systems or catheter designs. Whether validating suction performance for neurovascular stroke or measuring extraction efficiency for coronary MI, our catheterization laboratories provide the pressure measurement capabilities and clot models direct aspiration validation requires.

carotid-stent-testing.title: Carotid Stent Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
carotid-stent-testing.heroDescription: Success in carotid stenting depends on opening blocked arteries without releasing plaque fragments that could cause stroke. We test how your device compresses plaque, measure particles released during deployment, track vessel scaffolding performance, and verify that cerebral blood flow remains adequate throughout the procedure.
carotid-stent-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Carotid stents face a unique challenge that doesn't exist in other vascular territories. The plaque you're treating is the same material that causes stroke if fragments break loose. Your device must compress unstable plaque against the vessel wall, maintain that compression long-term, and accomplish both without releasing particles into cerebral circulation. This requires testing that tracks embolic generation during every phase of deployment while verifying that the stent provides adequate vessel scaffolding.

We test carotid stents using anatomically accurate carotid bifurcation models with pulsatile flow systems that replicate cerebral circulation patterns. High-resolution particle tracking captures debris released during deployment and expansion, measuring both size and quantity of embolic material. Flow velocity measurement confirms adequate cerebral perfusion throughout the procedure, while radial force testing validates that your stent maintains plaque compression under arterial pressure. We evaluate both self-expanding nitinol designs and balloon-expandable systems across different stenosis severities and plaque compositions.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for carotid stent devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates embolic safety during deployment, adequate revascularization of the stenosed segment, and maintained vessel patency over time. We measure performance against ISO 25539 standards for cardiovascular stents, with specific emphasis on cerebrovascular safety parameters that distinguish carotid applications from coronary or peripheral use.

aaa-device-testing.title: AAA Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
aaa-device-testing.heroDescription: Successful aneurysm repair requires stent grafts that seal completely against vessel walls under continuous aortic pressure, prevent blood from leaking back into the aneurysm sac, and maintain that seal for years without migration. We test high-pressure containment performance, measure all four types of endoleaks, validate modular component integration, and confirm your device withstands the mechanical stresses of the aortic environment.
aaa-device-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm repair presents a unique challenge in vascular intervention. Your stent graft must contain blood under the highest pressures in the body while sealing against vessel walls that may be irregular, calcified, or angulated. Any gap between the device and vessel wall creates an endoleak that defeats the purpose of the repair. The device must also resist the constant downward force of pulsatile blood flow that can cause migration over time.

We test AAA devices using high-pressure aortic simulators that replicate systolic pressures up to 200 mmHg with anatomically accurate aneurysm models. Pressure sensors throughout the system detect any blood flow into the aneurysm sac, identifying Type I endoleaks at attachment zones, Type II leaks from branch vessels, Type III leaks between modular components, and Type IV leaks through graft material. We measure the force required to dislodge your device, test seal integrity across different neck angulations and diameters, and run accelerated fatigue cycles that simulate decades of cardiac pulsation. Both modular multi-component systems and unibody designs undergo testing across the anatomical variations you'll encounter clinically.

Our protocols follow FDA guidance for endovascular AAA devices, typically pursuing the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates complete aneurysm exclusion, adequate seal zone fixation, and maintained structural integrity over the intended device life. We measure performance against ISO 7198 standards for cardiovascular implants, with specific emphasis on high-pressure containment and long-term durability requirements unique to aortic applications.

ivc-filter-testing.title: IVC Filter Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
ivc-filter-testing.heroDescription: Successful IVC filters must capture life-threatening clots traveling toward the lungs while preserving venous blood flow back to the heart, resist migration in high-volume flow, and allow safe retrieval weeks or months later. We test clot capture efficiency across different clot sizes, measure venous flow obstruction, quantify retrieval forces after extended deployment, and validate that your filter remains stable without perforating the vena cava wall.
ivc-filter-testing.primaryContentDescription:
IVC filters face a paradox that defines their challenge. The device must catch clots that could cause fatal pulmonary embolism, yet those same struts or wires that capture emboli also obstruct the venous flow needed to return blood to the heart. Capture too much and you create venous congestion. Miss fragments and you fail to prevent embolism. The filter must also anchor securely in a vessel that carries enormous blood volume without tilting, migrating, or perforating through the vessel wall.

We test IVC filters using venous flow simulators that replicate inferior vena cava hemodynamics with flow rates up to 5 liters per minute. Synthetic clots of varying sizes challenge your filter's capture efficiency while flow sensors measure pressure gradients that indicate venous obstruction. We track filter position under pulsatile flow to detect migration or tilting, measure the force required to retrieve your device after simulated implantation periods, and validate that retrieval hooks or mechanisms remain accessible. Testing includes both permanent filters designed for indefinite placement and retrievable designs across the range of IVC diameters encountered clinically, from 15mm to 30mm vessel sizes.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for IVC filter devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates adequate clot capture for pulmonary embolism prevention, minimal venous flow obstruction, secure positioning without perforation risk, and reliable retrieval for temporary designs. We measure performance against ISO 25539 standards for cardiovascular implants, with specific emphasis on venous safety parameters and retrieval system reliability.

capabilities.description: We test filter performance as captured clot volume increases, measuring at what point accumulated thrombus begins to obstruct venous flow and whether your device maintains stability under increasing embolic load.

embolic-protection-testing.title: Embolic Protection Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
embolic-protection-testing.heroDescription: Successful embolic protection requires devices that capture plaque debris without blocking blood flow to critical organs, contain all captured material during retrieval, and deploy reliably in the seconds available during high-risk procedures. We test particle capture efficiency down to 40 microns, measure flow obstruction at the filter, validate debris retention during device collapse and removal, and confirm your system deploys accurately in tortuous vascular anatomy.
embolic-protection-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Embolic protection devices face competing demands that make testing critical. Your filter or occlusion system must catch particles that could cause stroke, heart attack, or organ damage, yet the same pores or mechanisms that capture debris also restrict blood flow to tissue that depends on continuous perfusion. Deploy too slowly and emboli escape before protection activates. Retrieve carelessly and captured debris spills back into circulation. The device must accomplish all this during procedures where seconds matter and anatomical access may be challenging.

We test embolic protection devices using programmable debris generators that release controlled quantities of synthetic particles sized from 40 microns to 5 millimeters. High-speed imaging tracks what your filter captures versus what passes through, while flow sensors measure pressure gradients that indicate perfusion compromise. We validate that your device deploys within the time window available during actual procedures, test debris retention as the filter collapses for retrieval, and confirm that captured material remains contained during catheter withdrawal. Testing covers distal filter systems used in carotid and peripheral interventions, proximal occlusion devices for cerebral protection, and specialized designs for specific anatomical territories across vessel diameters from 3mm to 8mm.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for embolic protection devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates adequate particle capture for procedural safety, minimal flow obstruction during deployment, complete debris containment during retrieval, and reliable performance across relevant vascular territories. We measure capture efficiency against benchmarks established for cerebral protection during carotid stenting, coronary intervention safety, and peripheral vascular procedures.

laa-closure-testing.title: LAA Closure Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
laa-closure-testing.heroDescription: Comprehensive preclinical testing for left atrial appendage closure devices with deployment accuracy, sealing effectiveness assessment, and anatomical compatibility validation across diverse appendage morphologies.
laa-closure-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Left atrial appendage closure devices prevent stroke in atrial fibrillation patients by permanently sealing the appendage where blood clots form. These devices face unique validation challenges across diverse appendage anatomies, from chicken wing to cauliflower configurations, requiring precise deployment mechanics and complete sealing without peridevice leaks. Success depends on demonstrating anatomical compatibility across morphological variants, positioning accuracy during cardiac motion, and endothelialization that ensures permanent closure.

We evaluate deployment accuracy using transesophageal echocardiography and high-resolution fluoroscopy that capture device positioning throughout complete cardiac cycles. Our catheterization laboratories feature specialized left atrial access capabilities, anatomical models representing morphological variations, and flow measurement systems that quantify sealing effectiveness. From device-tissue interface characterization to chronic endothelialization assessment, our protocols address the specific performance requirements LAA closure technologies demand.

ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide chronic implantation studies while device specific protocols address deployment mechanics and anatomical compatibility validation. Our GLP compliant testing supports both 510(k) pathways demonstrating substantial equivalence to predicate devices and PMA submissions for breakthrough technologies. Whether validating nitinol framework designs or novel sealing mechanisms, our protocols address FDA expectations for stroke prevention devices across diverse patient anatomies.

watchman-device-testing.title: Watchman Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
watchman-device-testing.heroDescription: Specialized preclinical validation for Watchman LAA occluders with nitinol framework characterization, fabric membrane assessment, and device stability testing across varying appendage anatomies.
watchman-device-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Watchman devices represent the established standard for percutaneous LAA closure, requiring validation that addresses nitinol framework expansion, polyester fabric membrane sealing, and sizing accuracy across diverse appendage geometries. These self-expanding occluders must demonstrate controlled deployment, adequate wall apposition force, and complete appendage isolation while supporting endothelialization that prevents thrombus formation. Success depends on validating framework durability under cardiac loading, membrane integrity throughout device lifetime, and optimal sizing across the spectrum of LAA anatomical variations.

We evaluate framework performance using specialized expansion testing that quantifies radial force, shape memory recovery, and deployment consistency across temperature ranges. Our catheterization laboratories feature transesophageal echocardiography capabilities, anatomical models representing chicken wing through windsock morphologies, and flow measurement systems that assess sealing effectiveness. From nitinol fatigue characterization to fabric endothelialization studies, our protocols address the specific validation requirements Watchman platforms demand.

ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide nitinol and fabric material assessment while device specific protocols address compression ratio optimization and anchoring stability validation. Our GLP compliant testing supports both 510(k) pathways for devices demonstrating substantial equivalence to established Watchman predicates and PMA submissions for significant design modifications. Whether validating next generation framework designs or novel fabric configurations, our protocols address FDA expectations for LAA closure devices across intended patient populations.

renal-denervation-testing.title: Renal Denervation Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
renal-denervation-testing.heroDescription: Specialized preclinical validation for catheter-based renal denervation systems with sympathetic nerve ablation assessment, energy delivery characterization, and chronic reinnervation evaluation.
renal-denervation-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Renal denervation devices treat resistant hypertension by disrupting sympathetic nerves surrounding renal arteries. These catheter-based systems must prove they can achieve complete nerve ablation while preserving renal artery integrity and kidney function. Whether using radiofrequency energy or ultrasound, devices need validation showing sustained blood pressure reduction without nerve regrowth over time.

We test nerve ablation effectiveness through specialized immunohistochemistry that visualizes sympathetic fiber destruction, measuring norepinephrine levels to confirm functional denervation, and tracking blood pressure changes that demonstrate therapeutic benefit. Our protocols evaluate energy delivery consistency across varying vessel anatomies, ensuring circumferential ablation without creating arterial injury. From acute safety assessment through extended reinnervation studies, our testing addresses the complete validation path these hypertension devices require.

ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide chronic arterial contact assessment while FDA guidance for neurological devices informs ablation validation protocols. Our testing supports both early feasibility studies under IDE applications and comprehensive PMA submissions. Whether validating radiofrequency catheter designs or ultrasound transducer arrays, our protocols demonstrate the ablation completeness and renal safety FDA expects for hypertension treatment devices.

capabilities.title: Chronic Reinnervation Evaluation

capabilities.description: Delivery system testing evaluates navigation through renal anatomy and electrode positioning while impedance monitoring confirms tissue contact and multi-electrode systems demonstrate circumferential ablation coverage.

whyChooseCards.text: Our data packages have supported FDA submissions for ablation-based therapeutic devices across multiple tissue targets. We understand neurological device guidance requirements, energy delivery safety validation, and the comprehensive efficacy demonstration FDA expects for devices treating systemic conditions through targeted nerve disruption addressing both acute ablation completeness and long-term therapeutic durability.

endoscopic-device-testing.title: Endoscopic Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
endoscopic-device-testing.heroDescription: Successful endoscopy depends on cameras that see tissue clearly, flexible shafts that navigate anatomy without breaking, and components that survive repeated cleaning cycles. We test optical resolution per ISO 8600 standards, measure mechanical durability through thousands of bending cycles, and validate that your scope maintains performance after the cleaning protocols hospitals actually use.
endoscopic-device-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Endoscopic cameras must resolve enough detail for accurate diagnosis while maintaining color accuracy under varying light conditions. The flexible insertion tube must bend through tight turns without kinking, transmit physician hand movements precisely to the tip, and return to its original shape after each procedure. Meanwhile, working channels must stay patent for instrument passage, and the entire system must withstand hundreds of cleaning and sterilization cycles without degrading optical or mechanical performance.

We measure image resolution across your camera's full field of view using ISO 8600 test patterns. Mechanical testing quantifies minimum bending radius, torque transmission from handle to tip, and structural integrity after 10,000+ flexion cycles. We validate that seals maintain integrity during high-pressure cleaning, that optical components resist fogging and contamination, and that electrical insulation remains intact throughout your scope's claimed lifetime. Testing follows protocols specific to GI, bronchial, urological, and laparoscopic applications.

Your regulatory pathway depends on demonstrating that optical performance meets diagnostic requirements, mechanical components survive clinical use patterns, and biocompatibility testing addresses mucosal contact duration per ISO 10993. We provide the data packages needed for 510(k) submissions, with protocols designed around FDA guidance for flexible endoscopes and the specific contact scenarios your device encounters during procedures.

capabilities.title: Optical Resolution Testing
capabilities.description: We measure how many line pairs per millimeter your camera resolves at center and periphery, quantifying whether image quality supports diagnostic decisions across the full viewing area per ISO 8600 standards.

capabilities.title: Mechanical Flexibility Validation
capabilities.description: We determine the tightest radius your scope navigates without kinking or breaking, measuring insertion force, torque response, and whether the shaft maintains flexibility after repeated bending to maximum specifications.

capabilities.title: Channel Patency Assessment
capabilities.description: We verify that working channels pass instruments of specified diameters, maintain suction capacity, and resist blockage from tissue or fluid debris during simulated procedures.

capabilities.title: Cleaning Validation Testing
capabilities.description: We measure whether your scope's design allows complete removal of organic matter from channels and components, using the automated reprocessing systems hospitals actually employ.

capabilities.title: Illumination Uniformity Measurement
capabilities.description: We quantify light distribution across your scope's field of view, measuring whether illumination intensity varies enough to create diagnostic blind spots or misleading shadows.

capabilities.title: Biocompatibility Evaluation
capabilities.description: We conduct ISO 10993 cytotoxicity, sensitization, and irritation testing based on mucosal contact duration, providing the safety data required for tissue-contacting components.

whyChooseCards.text: Our facility includes specialized equipment for testing devices that must navigate complex anatomy. whyChooseCards.text: We maintain ISO 8600-compliant optical test benches with resolution targets, color charts, and illumination measurement systems. We can identify whether optical degradation stems from lens quality, fiber bundle damage, or sensor limitations, then correlate findings with your manufacturing specifications.

laparoscopic-testing.title: Laparoscopic Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
laparoscopic-testing.heroDescription: Successful laparoscopic surgery requires instruments where electrical insulation never fails during tissue cutting, trocar seals maintain pneumoperitoneum throughout procedures, and articulation joints deliver precise movements after thousands of cycles. We test whether your electrosurgical insulation withstands the mechanical stress of tissue manipulation, measure how much force surgeons need to actuate your instrument, and validate that seals prevent gas leakage under the pressure conditions surgeons actually encounter.
laparoscopic-testing.primaryContentDescription:
Laparoscopic instruments combine mechanical precision with electrical safety in an environment where insulation failure can cause serious patient injury. Electrosurgical devices must deliver cutting or coagulation energy while maintaining complete insulation integrity along shaft lengths of 30-45cm. Articulating instruments must transmit hand movements through multiple joints without backlash or position drift. Trocars must seal around instruments of varying diameters while maintaining 12-15 mmHg insufflation pressure. All components must survive repeated sterilization cycles without performance degradation.

We measure insulation resistance per IEC 60601 standards, applying mechanical stress while monitoring for current leakage that could cause patient burns. Mechanical testing quantifies actuation forces at the handle, jaw closure forces at the tip, and whether articulation accuracy degrades after 5,000+ cycles. We validate trocar seal performance across instrument diameter ranges, measure CO2 leak rates during simulated instrument exchanges, and verify that valve mechanisms maintain function after repeated autoclaving. Testing addresses general surgery, gynecological, and urological applications.

Your device typically follows a 510(k) pathway demonstrating substantial equivalence to predicate instruments. We provide testing that addresses FDA guidance on electrosurgical safety, mechanical performance verification, and biocompatibility assessment for peritoneal tissue contact per ISO 10993. Our protocols generate the comparative data and safety documentation regulators expect for laparoscopic instrument clearances.

capabilities.title: Electrosurgical Insulation Testing
capabilities.description: We measure whether electrical insulation maintains integrity when your instrument bends to maximum radius during tissue manipulation, detecting failure points before they cause patient injury in clinical use per IEC 60601 requirements.

capabilities.title: Trocar Seal Performance Validation
capabilities.description: We quantify CO2 leak rates when instruments of different diameters pass through your trocar seal, measuring whether pneumoperitoneum is maintained during the rapid instrument exchanges that occur in actual surgical procedures.

capabilities.title: Articulation Durability Assessment
capabilities.description: We cycle articulating joints through 10,000+ movements while measuring position accuracy, determining whether backlash develops that would compromise surgical precision during complex dissection maneuvers.

capabilities.title: Tissue Grasping Force Measurement
capabilities.description: We quantify how much force your jaws apply to tissue when surgeons close the handles completely, verifying adequate grip strength without tissue damage that could cause inadvertent bleeding or perforation.

capabilities.title: Ergonomic Force Analysis
capabilities.description: We measure how much hand strength surgeons need to actuate your instrument over extended procedures, identifying whether actuation forces cause fatigue that could compromise surgical performance during lengthy operations.

capabilities.title: Sterilization Compatibility Testing
capabilities.description: We validate that repeated exposure to steam sterilization, high-level disinfection, or other reprocessing methods does not degrade mechanical performance, electrical safety, or material properties throughout your instrument's claimed lifetime.

whyChooseCards.text: Our laboratory includes IEC 60601-compliant test systems that measure leakage current while instruments undergo mechanical stress. This equipment supports the electrical safety documentation FDA expects for electrosurgical instruments across all specialized surgical applications.

whyChooseCards.text: We've tested precision surgical instruments for 40 years, developing expertise in the mechanical performance and durability requirements that determine clinical success. Our team understands how surgeons actually use laparoscopic tools, which failure modes matter most, and how to design test protocols that predict real-world performance. This experience translates directly to identifying problems early in development.

whyChooseCards.text: All testing follows GLP protocols per 21 CFR Part 58, with documentation systems designed around FDA submission requirements. Our study directors understand what regulators look for in laparoscopic instrument testing data. We've supported successful 510(k) clearances for electrosurgical devices, mechanical instruments, and combination products with this approach.
